history.content: Generally speaking, it will give you greater mathematical maturity (in case you want to take theory courses). It has applications in cryptography, automata theory, and complexity theory (e.g. the Graph Isomorphism problem). I would only take Math 113 if I was interested in getting into CS theory. Otherwise, it is pretty useless application-wise. However, I would highly recommend taking it if you have the time!

Generally speaking, it will give you greater mathematical maturity (in case you want to take theory courses). It has applications in cryptography, automata theory, and complexity theory (e.g. the Graph Isomorphism problem). I would only take Math 113 if I was interested in getting into CS theory. Otherwise, it is pretty useless.

Generally speaking, it will give you greater mathematical maturity (in case you want to take theory courses). It has applications in cryptography, automata theory, and complexity theory (e.g. the Graph Isomorphism problem). 

I would only take upper-division math classes if I was interested in getting into CS theory.

Generally speaking, it will give you greater mathematical maturity (in case you want to take theory courses). It has applications in cryptography, automata theory, and complexity theory (e.g. the Graph Isomorphism problem). 

Honestly speaking, I would only take upper-division math classes if I was interested in getting into CS theory.
A lot of CS students take 113 for fun. What are the applications of 113 in CS? How will it help me?
history.subject: Taking Math 113 (Abstract Algebra)
